item.item: The reference of the taxonomic standard in which the current taxon is published.
This attribute holds the internet address in which the current taxon is published.
The level or relative position in the taxonomic hierarchy.
This attribute holds the enumerated value describing the rank or position in the taxonomic hierarchy.
This type defines the enumerated set of all taxonomic ranks.
The highest taxonomic rank or relative position in the taxonomic hierarchy.
The second highest taxonomic rank below domain in the taxonomic hierarchy.
A subclass of the kingdom rank in the taxonomic hierarchy.
A subclass of the kingdom rank in the taxonomic hierarchy.
The taxonomic rank above phylum or division and below kingdom in the taxonomic hierarchy. In botany, the term superdivision is used in place of superphylum.
The taxonomic rank below kingdom and above class in the taxonomic hierarchy. In botany, the term division is used in place of phylum.
The taxonomic rank below phylum or division and above infraphylum in the taxonomic hierarchy.
The taxonomic rank below subphylum and above microphylum in the taxonomic hierarchy.
The taxonomic rank below infraphylum in the taxonomic hierarchy.
The taxonomic rank above class in the taxonomic hierarchy.
The taxonomic rank below superclass and above subclass in the taxonomic hierarchy.
The taxonomic rank below class and above infraclass in the taxonomic hierarchy.
The taxonomic rank below subclass and above parvclass in the taxonomic hierarchy.
The taxonomic rank below infraclass in the taxonomic hierarchy.
The taxonomic rank below class and above cohort in the taxonomic hierarchy.
The taxonomic rank below legion in the taxonomic hierarchy.
The taxonomic rank above superorder in the taxonomic hierarchy.
The taxonomic rank above grandorder and below magnorder in the taxonomic hierarchy.
The taxonomic rank above mirorder and below superorder in the taxonomic hierarchy.
The taxonomic rank above order and below grandorder in the taxonomic hierarchy.
The taxonomic rank above suborder and below mirorder in the taxonomic hierarchy.
The taxonomic rank above infraorder and below order in the taxonomic hierarchy.
The taxonomic rank above parvorder and below suborder in the taxonomic hierarchy.
The taxonomic rank and below infraorder in the taxonomic hierarchy.
The taxonomic rank above family in the taxonomic hierarchy.
The taxonomic rank below superfamily and above subfamily in the taxonomic hierarchy.
The author of the family epithet in the taxonomic hierarchy.
The taxonomic rank below family in the taxonomic hierarchy.
The taxonomic rank above tribe in the taxonomic hierarchy.
The taxonomic rank below supertribe and above subtribe in the taxonomic hierarchy.
The taxonomic rank below tribe/em> in the taxonomic hierarchy.
The taxonomic rank above subgenus in the taxonomic hierarchy.
The author of the genus epithet in the taxonomic hierarchy.
The taxonomic rank below genus and above section in the taxonomic hierarchy.
The taxonomic rank below subgenus and above series in the taxonomic hierarchy.
The taxonomic rank below section in the taxonomic hierarchy.
The taxonomic rank above species in the taxonomic hierarchy.
The taxonomic rank below superspecies and above subspecies in the taxonomic hierarchy.
The author of the species epithet in the taxonomic hierarchy.
The taxonomic rank below species and above infraspecies in the taxonomic hierarchy.
The author of the subspecies epithet in the taxonomic hierarchy.
The taxonomic rank below subspecies and above form in the taxonomic hierarchy.
The author of the variety epithet in the taxonomic hierarchy.
The taxonomic rank below variety in the taxonomic hierarchy.
The author of the form epithet in the taxonomic hierarchy.

A group of cultivars. These can be roughly comparable to cultivar groups, but convarieties, unlike cultivar groups, do not necessarily contain named varieties, and convarieties are members of traditional "Linnaean" ranks.
A cultivar is a plant or grouping of plants selected for desirable characteristics that can be maintained by propagation.

The full scientific name comprising epithets and rank abbreviations, excluding authorship. Unless of higher rank, the name should start at the genus rank and provide the most specific infraspecies rank.
The scientific name authority at the lowest taxonomic rank.
The species epithet including its genus.
The taxonomic epithet comprising all elements below the rank of species in the taxonomic hierarchy.
The author of the lowest rank epithet in the taxonomic hierarchy.
The valid or preferred scientific name related to the current taxon.
Synonyms related to the current taxon.
Names of the taxon in colloquial language.
This type qualifies the taxon crop.
Taxonomy used by compiler to identify the material.
Synonyms references related to the current taxon.
Gene Pool to which the taxon belongs.
Citation of reference source for Gene Pool concept applied.
The group to which the taxon belongs, this group uses taxonomic classifications of the crop genus as a proxy for relative crossability.
Citation of reference source for Taxon Group concept applied.
The taxon infraspecific group to which the taxon belongs.
Citation of reference source for taxon sub-roup concept applied.
Database, literature or personal communication reference for listing of taxon as a crop wild relative or wild utilised species.
Designation of the primary or prioritized use of the associated crop or the wild utilised species taxon.
Notes on occurrence and designation status from databases, literature or personal communications.
Degree of closeness of relationship to crop taxon.
Scientific names of the associated crop to which the crop wild relative is related.
The vernacular names of the associated crop taxon to which the crop wild relative is related.
Economic Value of the Related Crop
Economic Value of the Related Crop reference

Citation of reference source for the economic value of the related crop or any bibliographic references related to the publication of the economic value, the format should include the author, date, title, journal, volume and page number or the DOI number.
Andromonoecious (Plants have some male and hermaphrodite flowers)
Gynodioecious (Plants have female and hermaphrodite flowers)
Dioecious (Having either only male or only female flowers. No individual plant of the population produces both pollen and ovules)
Have stems that are woody and persistent, and buds that are normally exposed 3 m or more above ground level. This category includes trees and large shrubs.)
Also have woody, persistent stems, but are lower in stature with buds typically located between 0.5 m and 3 m above ground level. This category includes smaller shrubs.)
Have herbaceous stems that persist for several years and include tropical species such as bananas and plantains.)
Can have stems that are herbaceous or woody and persistent, and have buds that are located above soil level, but never by more than 50 cm. This group includes dwarf shrubs and some perennial herbs.)

Have herbaceous stems that often die-back during unfavourable seasons, and surviving buds placed on (or just below) soil level. This group includes many biennial and perennial herbs, including those in which buds grow from a basal rosette.)
Have stems that die back during unfavorable seasons, with the plant surviving as a bulb, rhizome, tuber or root bud.)
Have stems that die back during unfavorable seasons, with the plant surviving as a bulb, rhizome, tuber or root bud.)
Grow on other plants (their growing buds occur on another plant).)

Plants in which surviving buds are buried in water-saturated soil, or below water-level, but that have flowers and leaves that are fully emergent during the growing season. The group includes many marsh and emergent aquatic herbs.)

Are fully aquatic herbs in which surviving buds are submerged, or buried in soil beneath water. Their stems and vegetative shoots grow entirely underwater and leaves can be submerged or floating, but only the flower-bearing parts may be emergent.)
Dispersal via ingestion by vertebrate animals- mostly birds and mammals.

The taxon is indigenous within the area concerned, and there is evidence that it has a history there, or circumstantial evidence of occurrence in one or more natural or semi-natural plant communities.
Assumed to be Native in the area concerned. The assumption may be made, for example, on the basis of evidence of vegetation community structure etc.
There is doubt as to whether the status of the plant in the area concerned is native, as defined above, or not. All records about the native status of the plant in the area are in doubt.

The plant is native, doubtfully native or assumed to be native in the area concerned and has become Extinct as such. The criterion of extinction is that the plant was not found (as a native) after repeated searches of known or likely areas (i.e. sites within the area covered by the record), even though the plant may be extant elsewhere.
The plant is definitely not native (as defined above) in the area concerned.

The plant has been recorded as native in the area concerned but all of those records have been disproved or discounted. A known fallacious native record must have been made, and it must be known that the plant does not occur as a native in the area to use this record.
Notes on taxon occurrence or status.
Type of legislation in which the taxon is included.
This type qualifies the red list assessment geographic level.
Other Red List categories and criteria

Red List category, criteria and subcriteria that apply to the taxon as a result of the Red listing process using the alternative system, if the taxon has not been assessed using the IUCN Red List Categories and Criteria Version 3.1.
Year of IUCN Red List assessment
Year in which Red List assessment was carried out [YYYY].
URL publication details of Red List assessment
URL linking to the additional Red List assessment publication details.
References details of Red List assessment
Any bibliographic references related to the publication of the checklist, the format should include the author, date, title, journal, volume and page number or the DOI number.
Threaten status according to national criteria
Threat status according to national criteria.
Year of national red list assessment
This type qualifies the period of occurrence of the threat.
Group covering the list of crops covered in the Annex 1 of the International Treaty on Plant Genetic Resources for Food and Agriculture.
This type enumerates the list of crops covered in the Annex 1 of the International Treaty on Plant Genetic Resources for Food and Agriculture.
